elements.name: question9
elements.title: Why is it more difficult to understand passive sentences than active sentences?
elements.correctAnswer: The content must be read against the direction of reading (from back to front).

elements.name: question4
elements.title: How are sentences formed in the passive voice? Give an example.
elements.correctAnswer: Auxiliary verb "werden" plus Partizip II; example: We will be/were informed about it.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: How are sentences formed in the passive voice? Give an example.
elements.correctAnswer: Auxiliary verb "to be" plus participle II; example: We are/were informed about it.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: What are the stylistic advantages of active sentences?
elements.correctAnswer: They are more dynamic, more direct, shorter and easier to understand.

elements.name: question1
elements.title: In which situations should passive sentences be avoided?
elements.correctAnswer: In the case of negative messages, the actors (those responsible) should not "hide" behind passive sentences.

elements.name: question6
elements.title: What is the form and time of the previous interrogative sentence?
elements.correctAnswer: passive, present tense (with the modal verb "should")
